description: Video surveillance system installation and configuration

questions.question: What does CCTV stand for?
questions.explanation: CCTV (Closed-Circuit Television) refers to video systems where signals are transmitted to specific monitors, not broadcast publicly like television.

questions.question: What is an IP camera?
options: A network camera that transmits video over IP networks
questions.explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) cameras digitize video at the camera and transmit it over standard Ethernet networks using IP addressing.

questions.question: What is resolution in video surveillance?
options: The number of pixels that make up the video image
questions.explanation: Resolution refers to pixel count (e.g., 1920×1080 for 1080p). Higher resolution provides more detail for identification and evidence.

questions.question: What is 1080p resolution?
questions.explanation: 1080p (Full HD) is 1920 × 1080 pixels, approximately 2 megapixels. The 'p' stands for progressive scan.

questions.question: What is an NVR?
options: Network Video Recorder - records IP camera video
questions.explanation: NVR (Network Video Recorder) receives and records video from IP cameras over the network, storing it to hard drives for playback and evidence.

questions.question: What is a DVR in surveillance?
options: Digital Video Recorder for analog cameras
questions.explanation: DVR (Digital Video Recorder) converts analog camera signals to digital and stores recordings. NVRs are used for IP cameras.

questions.question: What cable type is most common for IP cameras?
questions.explanation: IP cameras connect via Cat 5e or Cat 6 Ethernet cable, which can also provide power via PoE (Power over Ethernet).

questions.question: What is PoE in camera systems?
options: Power over Ethernet - delivering power and data on one cable
questions.explanation: PoE (Power over Ethernet) delivers DC power and network data over the same Ethernet cable, eliminating separate power cables for cameras.

questions.question: What is the frame rate of video?
options: Number of images captured per second (fps)
questions.explanation: Frame rate (fps - frames per second) determines video smoothness. Standard rates are 30 fps (smooth) or 15 fps (saves storage).

questions.question: What is infrared (IR) illumination on cameras?
options: LEDs providing invisible light for night vision
questions.explanation: IR illuminators emit infrared light invisible to humans but visible to camera sensors, enabling video recording in complete darkness.

questions.question: What is a PTZ camera?
questions.explanation: PTZ cameras have motors allowing remote pan (left/right), tilt (up/down), and zoom control for flexible coverage of large areas.

questions.question: What is a dome camera?
options: A camera housed in a dome-shaped enclosure
questions.explanation: Dome cameras are housed in dome-shaped enclosures that are vandal-resistant and make it difficult to determine camera direction.

questions.question: What is the maximum cable length for a standard PoE camera run?
questions.explanation: Standard Ethernet/PoE cable runs are limited to 100 meters (328 feet). Extenders or fiber can be used for longer distances.

questions.question: What is video compression?
options: Reducing video file size for efficient storage and transmission
questions.explanation: Video compression (H.264, H.265) reduces file sizes while maintaining quality, critical for storage capacity and network bandwidth.

questions.question: What is H.265 (HEVC)?
options: High Efficiency Video Coding - advanced compression reducing file size vs H.264
questions.explanation: H.265 (HEVC) provides approximately 50% better compression than H.264 at similar quality, reducing storage and bandwidth requirements.

questions.question: What is WDR in cameras?
options: Wide Dynamic Range - handling high contrast lighting
questions.explanation: WDR (Wide Dynamic Range) allows cameras to capture usable images in scenes with both very bright and very dark areas, like doorways with backlight.

questions.question: What is the minimum light level rating (lux) for camera specifications?
options: The lowest light level at which the camera produces usable images
questions.explanation: Minimum illumination (lux rating) specifies the lowest light level for acceptable video. Lower numbers mean better low-light performance.

questions.question: What storage calculation factors affect NVR capacity?
options: Resolution, frame rate, compression, camera count, and retention days
questions.explanation: Storage needs depend on: cameras × resolution × frame rate × compression efficiency × hours/day × retention days. Manufacturers provide calculators.

questions.question: What is camera field of view (FOV)?
options: The area visible through the camera lens
questions.explanation: Field of view is the angular extent of the scene visible through the lens. Wider FOV covers more area but with less detail per object.

questions.question: How does lens focal length affect field of view?
options: Shorter focal length = wider FOV; longer = narrower FOV
questions.explanation: Shorter focal length lenses (2.8mm) provide wider FOV. Longer focal lengths (50mm) provide narrow FOV with more detail at distance.

questions.question: What is a varifocal lens?
options: A lens with adjustable focal length for fine-tuning FOV
questions.explanation: Varifocal lenses have manually adjustable focal length (e.g., 2.8-12mm), allowing FOV adjustment during installation. Motorized versions allow remote adjustment.

questions.question: What is motion detection in cameras?
options: Video analytics detecting movement in the scene for alerts/recording
questions.explanation: Motion detection analyzes video for pixel changes indicating movement. It can trigger alerts, start recording, or mark video for easy review.

questions.question: What is ONVIF?
options: Open Network Video Interface Forum - interoperability standard
questions.explanation: ONVIF is an industry standard ensuring IP cameras and recorders from different manufacturers can work together (interoperability).

questions.question: What is the IP rating for outdoor cameras?
options: Ingress Protection rating for water/dust resistance (e.g., IP66)
questions.explanation: IP ratings (IP65, IP66, IP67) indicate enclosure protection against dust and water. Higher numbers mean better protection for outdoor use.

questions.question: What PoE standard provides 30 watts for cameras?
questions.explanation: IEEE 802.3at (PoE+) provides up to 30W for devices. Standard PoE (802.3af) provides 15.4W. PoE++ (802.3bt) provides up to 60-100W.

questions.question: What is network bandwidth calculation for cameras?
options: Data rate needed to transmit video streams over the network
questions.explanation: Bandwidth (Mbps) required depends on resolution, frame rate, and compression. A 4MP camera at 30fps with H.265 typically needs 4-8 Mbps.

questions.question: What is video analytics?
options: Automated video analysis for detection (faces, objects, behaviors)
questions.explanation: Video analytics uses AI/algorithms to automatically analyze video for specific events - facial recognition, license plates, line crossing, loitering, etc.

questions.question: What is edge storage in cameras?
options: Recording directly to SD card in the camera
questions.explanation: Edge storage records video to an SD card in the camera itself. This provides backup if network fails and can reduce NVR load.

questions.question: What is camera cyber security best practice?
options: Change default passwords, use encryption, update firmware, segment network
questions.explanation: Secure camera installations require changing default passwords, enabling HTTPS/encryption, updating firmware, and isolating cameras on separate VLANs.

questions.question: What is megapixel count in cameras?
options: Total pixel count (width × height) in millions
questions.explanation: Megapixels = resolution width × height ÷ 1,000,000. 1080p (1920×1080) = 2.07MP. 4K (3840×2160) = 8.3MP.

questions.question: What is fisheye camera dewarping?
options: Software correction of 360° fisheye distortion into viewable perspectives
questions.explanation: Fisheye cameras capture 180° or 360° views with distortion. Dewarping software corrects this into normal-looking perspectives for viewing.

questions.question: What is RAID in NVR storage?
options: Redundant Array of Independent Disks for data protection
questions.explanation: RAID configurations (RAID 1, 5, 6) provide redundancy so video recordings survive hard drive failures. RAID 5 is common for NVRs.

questions.question: What is camera shutter speed?
options: Exposure time affecting motion blur and low-light performance
questions.explanation: Shutter speed (exposure time) affects motion blur (fast shutter freezes motion) and low-light sensitivity (slow shutter gathers more light).

questions.question: What is VMS software?
options: Video Management Software for viewing, recording, and managing cameras
questions.explanation: VMS (Video Management Software) is the platform for viewing live/recorded video, managing cameras, configuring analytics, and integrating with other systems.

questions.question: What is the difference between CBR and VBR compression?
options: CBR = constant bitrate; VBR = variable bitrate based on scene complexity
questions.explanation: CBR maintains constant bitrate regardless of scene. VBR adjusts bitrate based on scene complexity, saving storage during static scenes.

questions.question: What is a network switch uplink for cameras?
options: The connection from camera switch to core network/NVR
questions.explanation: The uplink connects the camera switch to the network core or NVR. It must have sufficient bandwidth for all camera streams combined.

questions.question: What is I-frame vs P-frame in video?
options: I-frame = complete image; P-frame = changes from previous frame
questions.explanation: I-frames (keyframes) are complete images. P-frames contain only changes from previous frames. This enables efficient compression.

questions.question: What is day/night camera mode?
options: Camera switches between color (day) and B&W IR-sensitive (night) modes
questions.explanation: Day/night cameras automatically switch from color mode in good light to B&W mode in low light for better IR sensitivity.

questions.question: What is camera tampering detection?
options: Analytics that detect camera blocking, repositioning, or defocusing
questions.explanation: Tampering detection alerts when cameras are blocked, spray-painted, moved, or defocused, indicating potential sabotage.

questions.question: What is privacy masking in cameras?
options: Blocking specific areas in the view from recording/display
questions.explanation: Privacy masks block designated areas (neighboring windows, private areas) from being recorded or displayed, addressing privacy concerns.
